metadata.case_name: Express Newspapers Pvt. Ltd. & Ors. v. Union of India & Ors.
metadata.case_number: Writ Petition Nos. 91, 99, 100, 101, 103, 116, 117, 118 of 1957; Civil Appeals Nos. 699-703 of 1957

facts.text: Newspaper industry in India originally started as individual newspapers founded by leaders but developed into profit-making industry with big industrialists investing and combines controlling several newspapers.
Working journalists agitated for impartial agency to fix wages, salaries, dearness allowance, retirement benefits, leave and conditions of service.
Uttar Pradesh Government appointed committee on June 18, 1947 to enquire into conditions of work of newspaper employees; reported March 31, 1949.
Central Provinces Berar Government appointed Inquiry Committee on March 27, 1948; reported same date with recommendations.
Prime Minister indicated during Parliament debates in 1951 appointment of committee or commission to examine state of Press.
Indian Federation of Working Journalists adopted resolution in April 1952 for Press Commission.

Government announced Press Commission on September 23, 1952 under Chairmanship of Shri Justice G. S. Rajadhyaksha; terms included enquiry into remuneration, conditions of employment of working journalists; reported July 14, 1954.

Press Commission found newspaper industry low profitability (6 lakhs profit on 7 crores capital, <1%); proof-readers generally not working journalists unless training for sub-editor; recommended minimum wage Rs. 125 + Rs. 25 DA; endorsed minimum wage concept tempered by industry capacity.
Press Commission concluded working journalists not 'workmen' under Industrial Disputes Act citing Bombay Tribunal in Jam-e-Jamshed and Patna HC in V.N.N. Sinha v. Bihar Journals Ltd.
Parliament passed Working Journalists (Industrial Disputes) Act, 1955 (I of 1955) on March 12, 1955 applying Industrial Disputes Act to working journalists.
Union Government introduced Bill No. 13 of 1955 on November 30, 1955; enacted as Working Journalists (Conditions of Service) and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 (45 of 1955) on December 20, 1955.

Act defines working journalist including proof-reader; applies Industrial Disputes Act with modifications; provides gratuity, hours of work (144 hrs/4 weeks), leave; constitutes Wage Board under s.8; s.9 criteria for wages; s.12 binding; applies Standing Orders and Provident Funds Acts to larger establishments.
Central Government notified Working Journalists Wage Board Rules, 1956 on July 30, 1956; constituted Wage Board on May 2, 1956 with Chairman H.V. Divatia and 3 employer reps, 3 journalist reps.
Wage Board held meetings from May 26, 1956; issued questionnaire; low response (381/5465); K.P. Kesava Menon resigned June 21, 1956, replaced by K.M. Cherian July 14, 1956.

Wage Board took oral evidence in 5 zones Sept 1956-April 1957; final deliberations March-April 1957; majority decisions on classification of newspapers (A-E by gross revenue), groups/chains by total revenue, employee groups I-IV, wage scales, DA, etc.; retrospective from May 2, 1956 for A-C, Nov 1, 1956 for D-E.
Employer reps appended minute of dissent on April 30, 1957 criticizing scales as too high, ignoring capacity, unfair chain classification, retrospective effect.
Chairman noted reasons for decisions, lower than Press Commission due to newsprint instability; hoped no closures; review after 3-5 years.
Wage Board decision published May 11, 1957; Madras Labour Commissioner circular May 30, 1957 for revenue reports.
Express Newspapers Pvt. Ltd. filed WP 91/1957 on June 13, 1957 challenging Act and Wage Board; followed by other WPs 99-101,103,116-118/1957.
Petitioners detailed financial burdens: Express Group increase Rs.5.43 lakhs annual + arrears; PTI Rs.4.05 lakhs; Free Press Rs.1.73 lakhs; etc.; argued collapse risk.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Working Journalists (Conditions of Service) and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 violates Articles 19(1)(a), 19(1)(g), 14, and 32 of the Constitution.
Whether the Wage Board decision is valid, including competence to fix scales of pay, retrospective operation, classification of chains/groups, consideration of capacity to pay.

petitioner_arguments.text: Act violates Art.19(1)(a) freedom of speech, Art.19(1)(g) trade/business, Art.14 equality, Art.32 remedy.
Wage Board not competent to fix scales of pay as 'rates of wages' excludes scales; ignored capacity to pay, special industry conditions; unfair chain classification; retrospective effect burdensome.
Implementation would cause financial collapse, closures, reduce employment and newspapers, against public interest.

respondent_arguments.text: No violation of Arts.19(1)(a), 19(1)(g), 14, 32; Wage Board function legislative not judicial/quasi-judicial.
Wage Board considered s.9 criteria, material/evidence; many unanimous decisions; competent for scales and retrospective effect; petitioners' finances not leading to collapse.

court_reasoning.text: Traced history from industry origins, state committees, Press Commission findings/recommendations, enactment of two 1955 Acts, Wage Board constitution/proceedings/questionnaire/evidence/deliberations/majority decisions/minute of dissent/chairman's note.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Necessary to appreciate contentions by historical context leading to Act.

court_reasoning.text: Wage Board had powers of Industrial Tribunal; low questionnaire response but analyzed replies, took zonal evidence; majority decisions on classifications, scales based on gross revenue averages.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unanimous on some, majority on others; dissent regretted but scales high per employers.

court_reasoning.text: Petitioners filed WPs challenging vires post-publication; detailed their chains/groups, employee numbers, projected burdens/arrears/gratuity etc.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Common pattern challenging Act/Wage Board on fundamental rights and capacity.

court_reasoning.text: Classified wages: living wage, fair wage, minimum wage; cited international definitions (Higgins, Australian Acts, US, etc.) emphasizing beyond subsistence for efficiency, education, amenities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Press Commission adopted tempered minimum wage concept considering capacity.

key_quotes.text: "A journalist occupies a responsible position in life and has powers which he can wield for good or evil. It is he who reflects and moulds public opinion."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Press Commission characterization justifying better wages to attract talent.

key_quotes.text: "Though the living wage is the target, it has to be tempered... by... capacity of the industry to pay."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Press Commission on minimum wage concept.

key_quotes.text: "Let the word minimum be dropped and let it be a proper wage board which will look into this question in all its aspects."
key_quotes.speaker: respondent_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Minister's reason for dropping 'minimum' from Bill.

key_quotes.text: "In fixing the rates of wages, we have based them on the condition of the newspaper industry as a whole and not on the effect which they will produce on a particular newspaper."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Wage Board Chairman's note on wage fixation principle.
